titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Captain Thomas, master of the Express, a vessel belonging to Mr: W. R. Gray, which left Boston about the middle of January, and after disposing of her Cargo at Gottenburg, came on to Cronstadt, this morning brought me a number of letters from our friends at Boston and Quincy; he arrived at Cronstadt the day before yesterday— Mr: Fisher and Mr: Malbone called upon me— Mr: Malbone is going immediately to Providence, with Captain Rea— I gave him a packet for the Secretary of State; one of those which Mr: Six desired me to forward, and one for Quincy— I was engaged all the morning, in reading the Letters and Newspapers— Dined with Mr: Six, and one of his usual Companies— Count Bussche & his brother—Count St: Julien. Count Rozewusky—M. de Laval—the Chevalier de Bray, & Count Lüxbourg were there— Madame de Bray left the City yesterday morning— M. de Rayneval came in after we had sat down to table— As almost all the Company was going to the Play, the party broke up immediately after dinner— I returned home and afterwards walked to the Summer Gardens and in them— They are in the antient style of gardening; a fashion of laying out grounds, for which I have retained a partiality, ever since the enchantment which I felt from them when in the Spring of 1778 I first saw them in France— But the Statues, which are numerous, are almost all defaced or mutilated— Instead of elegant ornaments, they are in their present condition the greatest deformity of the gardens— Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Maclure pass’d the Evening with us— They have just returned, from a tour to Schlüsselbourg— They intend going next week to Moscou.

2. I called this morning upon Count St: Julien, to request of him a Passport for Mr: Maclure, to enter the Austrian Territories— But the Count said that being here without a formal public character, he had no authority to give Passports. If however Mr: Maclure should enter by the way of Lemberg, he would give him a recommendation in the form of a Passport, which would be received as such by the Governor of Lemberg, and upon which he would furnish Mr: Maclure with his own Passport, to proceed. I went afterwards with Mrs: Adams to the apartments we have engaged, and considered the proper distribution of them for our family. This employed us, untill between 4 and 5. O’Clock— In the Evening we went to the German Play, and saw the Robbers of Schiller— It is very long, very extravagant, and with some interesting scenes, upon the whole very dull.

3. I had visits this morning from Mr: Six and Baron Blome; which consumed the greatest part of the time between the hours of breakfast, and of dinner— Baron Blome, brought me a message from Count Tolstoy, the Grand Maréchal de la Cour, of the Emperor, respecting Nelson, the black man who came with us from America— Nelson has been to him to obtain Service, as one of the Emperor’s blacks— But the Count sent me word, that he would not take him, unless it was my desire that he should— I desired Baron Blome, to thank Count Tolstoy, for his delicacy of proceeding, in this case— That as it would be making the fellow’s Fortune, to get him a place in the Emperor’s service, I should recommend him to it; only observing that he would require some attention to be kept a useful Servant, and that he had not been long enough in my Service, for me to be understood in my recommendation as answering for his good conduct— I gave him his character as far as I have observed it, and as favourably as I could consistently with truth.— I spoke to the Baron afterwards about the capture of American vessels, and of the report I had heard that in one of them some dispatches for me had been taken and opened. I told him that if I should receive a more authentic confirmation of this, I should take the Liberty of writing to him concerning it. He said he would readily transmit any representation that I should make in this matter to his Government, and expressed his regret at the circumstances which I had mentioned to him, of vessels captured, after having regularly pass’d, and paid the Sound duties at Elseneur.— The Ladies, Mr: Smith and myself dined at the Chevalier de Colombi’s—where we met Madame Betancourt, and her two daughters— The General, dined with the Emperor, but came after dinner— General Sabloukoff, and his Lady, were also there— Madame de Sabloukoff is a daughter of Mr: Angerstein of London— Mr: Navarro, and Mr: Harris were likewise of the Company— After dinner there was music— The Forte-Piano—Harp—Tambourine, Guittar, and Castagnettes— The two Miss Betancourt’s danced the Volero, with the Castagnettes. These little instruments
are made of a very hard South-American wood, called Grenadillo; each pair is made from one piece of wood, split so that the two parts correspond to each other in the grain, and scooped out to a form resembling marine shells— There is a difference in the tone of the right hand, from that of the left hand pair— They are of the same size, but not scooped out so thin, and emit stronger sounds— We came home about nine in the Evening; before Sunset, and I took a walk of half an hour upon the Quay.

4. The approaching departure of several American vessels for the United States, gives me constant occupation in writing letters and preparing packages to be sent by them— I was so employed all this morning, and it compels an intermission of my studies in the Russian language. I wrote this day to Judge Davis, and to my children— Attended this Evening the Lecture of Mr: Boucher, which after a very long procés verbal with its commentary, was upon Declarations of War— It is impossible to discover any system in his Course— And his starts are between Subjects so different from one another, that I scarcely can conceive how some of them have any relation to his course— He announced that there would be no Lecture next Thursday, on account of the Holiday—Ascension day. And that the public exhibition would be on Saturday; for which Tickets would be delivered. I walked about an hour after the Lecture, and then returned home and wrote untill past Midnight.

5. Visits this morning from Mr: Six; and from Dr: Graham, who came to announce his departure for America— He expects to go next Sunday; for Baltimore.— I wrote to my Mother.— This was a fine, and a warm day— I walk’d, morning and Evening— Mr: J. S. Smith passed an hour with us in the Evening.— Precisely at Midnight, I read a Chapter in the Bible, by the natural light of the place, without candles— Common sized print can be read as easily as at Mid-day.

6. This morning I received a packet from Count Romanzoff, enclosing letters for Mrs: Adams and Catherine, from Washington— They were under a cover of three or four lines from Mr: R. Forrest, in the Department of State; and came by a vessel dispatched by General Turreau to bring home the French fugitives from the Havanna. The letters, are to the 23d: of February, and bring the account of Eliza Johnson’s Marriage, with Mr: Pope, the member of the Senate from the State of Kentucky, on the 11th: of that Month— They are forwarded by General Armstrong from Paris, the 13th: of May. I paid visits to Mr: Maclure, Mr: Adgate, Mr Hurd, and Mr: Raimbert— Mr: Hurd only was at his lodgings. He is going immediately to Moscow— The rest of the day I was employed in preparing letters for America, to go by Captain Beckford— A Mr: Ihdanoff called upon me this day, with a recommendation from Monsieur de Laval; as a teacher of the Russian language— In returning from Mr: Raimbert’s I met Captain Beckford, just from Cronstadt, and who expects to sail in three or four days— We made an attempt to get seats this Evening at the great Theatre, but without success.

7. Mr: Plummer paid me a visit this day, and had some conversation with me respecting Mr Thorndike’s business— It was by the Russian Calendar Ascension day; one of their great Holidays— I took Waldstein with me, and went to look offer a collection of furniture and of pictures to be sold at Auction and the sale of which is to commence to-morrow— I afterwards went to the great shops and examined some Russian Furniture— Mr: Plummer dined, and passed the Evening with us. I had invited Captain Beckford, but he was so much engaged, in preparing for his departure that he did not come.

8. Captain Beckford, and Mr: Adgate paid me visits; and the Captain came to take charge of our packets and letters for America; his intention being to go down to Cronstadt to-morrow— I had also this morning a long visit from Mr: Six. I wrote letters— A Certificate in French and English for Captain Beckford, that he had brought me and my family out from America— And a Note to Count St: Julien, requesting his Passport for Mr: Maclure— As I was walking in the Evening on the Quay I met this Gentleman, who came home with me and pass’d a couple of hours with us— Mr: J. S. Smith also came during the latter part of the Evening.

9. I sent off this morning the letters and packets which are to go by Captain Beckford— Mr: Gray took them over to Mr: Glukoff’s— I went with Mrs: Adams, and examined furniture in a number of the Russian shops— Mr: Shreve called upon me for a Passport, which I furnished him; and one also to Mr: Hurd— Count St: Julien sent me that which I had requested for Mr: Maclure— At 7. in the Evening I attended the Public exhibition of Mr: Boucher’s disputants, on the question, whether “a Country, being a Peninsula, blockaded by Sea, and at the point of connection with the Continent having to contend against powerful armies; being without money, without credit; without connections—but having in abundance the most diversified productions, the means necessary for repelling force by force, and for subsistence, whether such a Country, in such a State, can carry on a great Commerce, pay its troops punctually and supply them with provisions?” The assembly was held at the house belonging to St: Peter’s School— The hearers were numerous, and among them were a few Ladies— The Dissertations, read were by Mr: Rachette, Count Alexander Khvostoff, Mr: Mayeur his Governor, Mr: Filetskoy, and Mr: Freygang— They were apparently written on both sides of the question, but the writers in the negative took care not to be too much in the right— The question itself without stating precisely the present political situation of Russia, bore too many of its essential features, to make a public discussion of its merits altogether impartial under such a Government as this— Mr: Boucher had announced that he should sum up the arguments of the several memorialists, and conclude with his own opinion— But he did little more than declare himself for the affirmative; and assigned little else in support of his opinion, but that the Commerce might be carried on, and the troops paid, by means of a Bank of deposit. The allusions to this Country, in the application of the question were frequent in all the memorials; and the compliments to the Emperor and his Minister numerous— Mr: Boucher, who called upon me on Thursday, with a dozen printed Invitations to this meeting, told me that he had received last Evening an anonymous Memoir, perfectly well written in the negative, which he believed was by Mr: Montréal— But it could not be read at the exhibition—first because it was anonymous; and secondly because it came too late— Mr: Raimbert, who also paid me a visit yesterday, told me that Maximin (Consolat) his grandson, had written that Memoir— Among the Auditors this Evening I met both the Counts Soltikoff, brothers, the Grand Master of Ceremonies Narishkin, the Turkish Capitan Bashaw, who bombarded the Seraglio, and a Monsieur Rudolphe, a Frenchman, who told me that he had been with me, at Mr: Le Coeur’s school, at Passi, in 1778, and enquired of our other American Schoolmates of that date, Cochran, Franklin Bache, and Deane— I have no doubt that this Gentleman’s memory, has been more retentive than mine, for I have no recollection of him— Nor indeed of any one name among Mr: Le Coeur’s French Scholars, though I well remember all the Americans— When we came home this Evening, I found a Notification from the Grand Master of Ceremonies, of a Court mourning, for the new Crown Prince of Sweden, Charles-Augustus; who died very suddenly upon the Parade, in reviewing some troops. The full, and half-mourning are to be worn each a week.

10. Mr: Laurance, a Gentleman, belonging to New-York, just arrived, from Stralsund, in an American vessel, brought me this morning a short letter from Dr: Mitchill of 15. January last, enclosing a copy of the President’s Message, and a Newspaper— I began to pack up, and send away books and Papers, to our future lodgings— I had also a long visit from the Chevalier Brancia— I took however a walk morning and Evening— Wrote to the Secretary of State, and read Massillon’s Sermon, upon the Assumption day of the Virgin Mary— This, though by no means the best is one of the most remarkable of this author’s Discourses— It was preached in a Convent of Nuns at Chaillot, the Church of which I recollect, and where at the time when the Sermon was delivered, the Widow of James the second, the cashiered King of England then resided—
One of the peculiarities of the discourse is, a violent censure upon the character of William 3. whom the right reverend Preacher styles an usurper, and of whom he undertakes to foretell, what History will say of him— This is a dangerous undertaking for a Sermon-writer; and History has not at all corresponded in this case with the Bishop’s prophecies— The Character of William 3. hitherto has been treated much too kindly by History— And English faction, has indeed been constantly interested to extol him for a Hero; and they have too successfully dictated the voice of History. William was a bad man, with great qualities; and unhappily such personages almost always impose upon the understanding of Posterity, as much or more than upon that of their own age. His conduct to John de Witt, was more base still than to James 2.— In both cases political motives trampled upon the most sacred sentiments of the human heart; upon gratitude to a benefactor, and to the strongest ties of kindred— Massillon dwells sufficiently upon this last reproach, without noticing the other— But as William was the champion of the British Patriots, his crimes have been extinguished in a blaze of glory, and History has had none of those delicacies for James 2. and his family, which the Bishop of Clermont thought proper to shew, while preaching in the presence of James’s widow.

11. I attended this morning a public auction of furniture and pictures; but made no purchases— Most of the pictures sold remarkably cheap— The other Articles in general very dear— Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray went upon a visit to Peterhoff, and perhaps to Cronstadt from which they did not return at Night— I attended Mr: Boucher’s Lecture, which was upon Letters of Marque, and the Etymology of the word Marque; and upon Blockades— His learning upon the first point was curious, but as usual undigested and confused— His remarks upon Blockades shallow, and incorrect— He announced an extraordinary meeting for next Saturday Evening to discuss the anonymous Memoir, on the question of last Saturday, the author of which he said, had made himself known to him— He propounded also a new question for discussion at a second public exhibition to be held in the Month of September—“Whether women are qualified to perform the Office of arbitrators”— To shew that this was no new question, he read a passage from the Code of Justinian declaring women incapable of acting as arbitrators, and annulling all decisions of women as such. There was no procès-verbal, this Evening—the public exhibition not having left time to prepare it— But it will not be lost— For Mr: Boucher observed that although objections had been made to this mode of lecturing, he should persist in it, being persuaded of its utility, from an experience of five and twenty years— I walked for about an hour after the lecture.

12. We were much engaged, all the morning, in preparations for our change of Residence— I attended at the public auction, but without success. While I was absent Dr: Graham called to take my dispatches for America; and the other packages— He went down to Cronstadt, to sail with the first fair wind, for Baltimore— Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Maclure also left the City this morning for Moscou— I went with Mrs: Adams to the shop where the Porcelain of the Manufacture is sold—and obtained a supply for the family use— I Dined with Mr: Six— Mr: Gourieff the Minister of Finance, and his Son, Count St: Julien, Baron Blome, & Mr: Krabbe, Prince Galitzin, General Pardo, &c formed the Company. Monsieur de Maisonneuve was also there, and told me that the order of Malta was suppressed here, and he should soon be turned out of his lodgings. I came home early; went to the Shop-Square with Mrs: Adams, and made some further purchases. Mr: Everett and Mr Gray, returned from their tour to Peterhoff, Oranienbaum and Cronstadt. Mr: Harris spent a couple of hours with us— A little before Midnight we removed from the Hotel de Bordeaux, where we have resided seven months, into the Apartments which were lately occupied by Count Einsiedel. They are in the house of Mr: Plinkey, forming the Corner of the Hobou Nepeydoa?, or New-Street, and of the Moika Canal— Our lodgings are on the Street— They afford better accommodations than those we have had, but we are obliged to part from Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray, not having room for them— They have engaged lodgings for themselves in another house.

13. The change of lodgings has cost me a Night’s rest, as has frequently happened in the course of my life.— The novelty of the situation produces an involuntary restlessness unfavourable to repose— I rose early this morning; but found myself too much wearied by the loss of sleep, and the Spirits too much dissipated for writing or reading— Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray, dined and passed the Evening with us.— I attended the Auction, and visited the shops with Mrs: Adams; where we made some further purchases. I walked an hour about the time of Sun-setting— Mr: Harris wrote me a line with a letter from Mr: Jewett announcing his arrival at Cronstadt, with dispatches for me from the Secretary of State— He afterwards called and passed an hour with us.

14. Mr: Harris sent me this morning another letter from Mr: Jewett, with a request for a Passport from me— It appears that he is detained at Cronstadt, but for what cause is not said— A Passport from me would not suffice.— After breakfast I called upon Mr: Harris, and found he had received another letter from Mr: Sparrow at Cronstadt, expressing an expectation to obtain the Admiral’s Passport, to come to St: Petersburg last Evening or at latest this morning— We thought it therefore unnecessary to apply to Count Romanzoff upon the subject this day— Mr: Jewett however did not arrive— Mr: Harris also asked my advice, respecting a vessel, which has arrived here with American Papers, from Copenhagen— The Aurora— She sailed from Boston in April 1809. belonging to Joseph Thomas, & Thomas Dingley of Plymouth; the latter of whom was her Captain— In August last, Dingley, for himself and Thomas, sold her at Liverpool in England to Barnabas Otis, said to be a Citizen of the United States, who came to the Baltic, took English Convoy, and pass’d through the Belt— She was taken by a Danish privateer, carried to Copenhagen and condemned— Bought by a Mr: M’Com, who also styles himself an American Citizen, and who as he says with the assistance of Mr: Saabye, and a Broker, obtained out of the Admiralty Court the vessel’s original papers, with which he came here, and claims admittance, under the American flag.— But this transaction is directly in violation of a Law of the United States— Captain Nimmo whom I saw at Copenhagen has arrived here likewise under Circumstances in other respects similar; but with this essential difference, that he was the purchaser of his own vessel, a case allowed by the Law of the United States— He came yesterday to see me— I concluded that Mr: Harris would be authorized by his Instructions from the Department of State to detain Mr: M’Com’s papers, as he intended to do— These circumstances detained me at Mr: Harris’s, untill 3. P.M. Mr: Everett dined with us— Mr: Gray at Mr: Glukoff’s. In the Evening I went to attend Mr: Boucher’s lecture; but found that he had changed his lodgings, and I did not discover to what place he had removed— Walk at the hour of Sun-setting.

15. Mr: Jewett, who arrived in the City last Evening, called and delivered to me, the dispatches, of which I had heard so much— They consisted of four newspapers with a line of enclosure from Mr: Forrest— Together with two letters, and some other papers from Mr: Joy at Copenhagen. Mr: Harris afterwards called upon me, and shewed me a letter from Gottenburg enclosing a declaration from the English Admiral, Saumarez, that no vessels, American or others will be permitted to come to Ports from which the British flag is excluded, without an English licence— In the Evening Mr: Harris sent me a number of Boston Newspapers of February and March, to the 24th: of the latter month— Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray dined and pass’d the Evening with us.

16. I attended the Auction of Furniture, and made at last a few purchases.— I met there Count Severin Potocki with whom I had some Conversation— The pictures all bear the names of great masters, but few of them are genuine, and still fewer of any value— The sale continued untill past 3. from which time untill nearly five I was walking— We went to the Great Theatre, and saw Voltaire’s Tragedy of Tancrede— Mademoiselle George performed the part of Aménaïde very well— That of Tancrede was misrepresented by one Wedel— The rest was tolerable, and no more— The after piece was a Ballet. La fille mal gardée— In which Monsieur Duport, and his Sister, Madame Batiste were performers.— In walking on Tuesday last the 12th: in the Summer Garden, I observed that there was scarcely a sign of vegetation upon the trees— I pass’d by the garden again this day, and found them all green— The leaves are in the process of expansion, but not yet fully unfolded— The Trees are principally lime-trees—

17. I was all this morning at home, without visitors; a case at present somewhat rare— I Dined with Count Bussche, the Westphalian Minister— The French Ambassador, and his Legation, with all the allied Legations were there. The Count’s House, and Furniture, and table were all highly magnificent— He has a Portrait of his Sovereign Jerome-Napoleon, in his royal robes, and the Crown on a table before him, painted with great elegance— I returned home early, that the Ladies might attend the Catherinenhoff ride, which is on this day of Pentecost, or Whitsunday a repetition of that on the first of May— But an accident to the wheel of the Carriage, before they reached the City Gate obliged the Ladies to walk home, and disappointed them of their ride— Mr: Fisher & Mr: Everett pass’d a couple of hours with us in the Evening— Mr: Six called while I was abroad, walking on the Quay. Mr: Smith dined at Mr: S. Cramer’s in the Country.

18. Long visits this morning from Mr: Adgate, and from the Chevalier de Navarro— Mr: Adgate came to inform me, that he intends to sail in three or four days for America; and would take charge of any letters I may wish to send— Mr: Navarro, has lodgings in the same house where we now reside, and formerly occupied our apartments— I walked this Evening in the Summer-Gardens, one alley of which was very much crowded with people; it being a holiday; the day after Pentecost, upon which it is the custom for the people of the lower Classes, thus to shew themselves in their finest dresses— The weather was unfavourable, which much diminished the Company— There were very few extraordinary dresses— Very few women, and scarcely any of them handsome— I came home soon after Sun-set—that is about ten in the Evening.

19. Visits this morning from Mr: Jewett and from Mr: Montréal— I attended at the Auction, and purchased a single article— In the Evening I returned visits to Mr: Jewett, Mr: Laurance, Mr: Dorsey, and Mr: Fisher, the last of whom only I found at home— Mr: Adgate and Mr: Everett were with him— His new partner Mr: Venning came in while I was there— Mr: Harris pass’d the remainder of the Evening with us— Mr: Montréal brought me a written account of the commerce of St: Petersburg, according to the request which I made sometime since to Mr: Raimbert, his uncle— He also brought me a Memoir against the prohibition to import refined sugars. I scarcely wrote any thing this day.

20. I made an attempt to escape visitors this morning— Mr: Six and Mr: Montréal called, without being admitted. But Mr: Fisher and Mr: Dorsey were received— They, with Mr: Jewett, Mr: Adgate, Mr: Harris and Mr: Laurance, dined with us— I accordingly did not walk out untill the Evening— But the occupations of the moment, and the furnishing the house still engross my time so much that I write nothing.

21. At the Auction this morning they were selling prints, many of which were sold at low prices— The Emperor who has been to Twer returned from his Journey yesterday morning. I was walking on the quay, and met General Pardo, and Count John Potocki The Count told us of the Courier arrived this morning with the news of Silistria being taken by General Kamensky and the army of Turkey— General Pardo told me that the Ukase, suppressing the ministry of Commerce, and dividing its functions between the Minister of the Interior for internal Commerce, and the Minister of Finance for the external, would be published to-morrow. I went to attend Mr: Boucher’s Lecture, but was too late— He has suspended the continuance of them untill the first of September, and changed his question, whether women should be allowed to sit as arbitrators, for a question whether the antient laws of bankruptcy should be restored. I walked to the Summer-gardens, and over the upper bridge— On returning I observed the Setting of the Sun this being the day of the Summer Solstice— It sets at 14 minutes past 9. and rises at 46 minutes past two in the morning— Soon after I came home, the messenger from the Master of the Ceremonies came with a notification that there would be a Te Deum performed at the Imperial chapel to-morrow morning at 11. O’Clock on account of the victories recently obtained over the Turks.— I closed the Evening at Chess with Mr: Smith.

22. I went, accompanied by Mr: Smith and Mr: Gray to the palace soon after eleven O’Clock; and after waiting about an hour we were introduced with the other members of the Corps diplomatique into the Imperial chapel— The Emperor, and Empress, Empress Mother, Grand-Duke Constantine, and Grand-Duchess Ann, with the Court, came in immediately afterwards The Metropolitan, the Archbishop, and the other officiating Priests, advanced to meet the Emperor and Empresses— The metropolitan successively presented to them the crucifix to kiss, and then the Emperor & the metropolitan at the same instant reciprocally kiss’d each other’s hand—the Ceremony with the Empresses was the same— And also with the Archbishop. The Priests then returned within the railing before the altar and immediately began to sing the Service— But the Emperor waved his hand to them to stop, and the Minister of War, Barclay de Tolly went within the railing, and read the report of the Victories, received from General Kamensky. The War Minister is not a good reader, and frequently found the manuscript almost illegible. When he had finished the reading of it, the Te Deum commenced again, and was about half-an hour long— The ceremonies of kissing the crucifix and the hands was then repeated, and the imperial family retired— There was no Cercle, for the foreign Ministers— After returning home, I attended the Auction— This was the day for selling the books; but I was too late. I walked to the Summer-gardens, and met General Pardo, who told me it was expected the English would take the island of Bornholm. I walked again in the Evening— Mr: Harris spent it with us, and I had also a visit from Mr: Wiggers the Agent of the Hanseatic towns—of which he tells me there are now only three—Lubeck, Hamburg and Bremen.

23. Visit this morning from Mr: Adgate, who informed me that he expected to go to Cronstadt the day after to-morrow, to sail in the ship Helvetius for Philadelphia— He promised also to call and take our letters— I attended the shops of the Silversmiths, and afterwards the public auction which this day came to a conclusion— I am still engaged much of my time in providing furniture for our apartments— I walked this Evening over to the island of St: Petersburg, across the Bridge, opposite the Summer-Gardens. Mr: Wiggers sent me Mallet’s History of the Hanseatic League, with a polite note.

24. Mr: Six, at the Te Deum, had invited me to dine with him to-morrow. He sent me this morning a note of apology, having just received information of the death of his Mother— Mr: Harris called upon me this forenoon, and mentioned that Count Romanzoff had last Evening received Dispatches from Mr: Daschkoff, with the account of some very unpleasant occurrences, at his House, at a fête which he gave on the anniversary of the Emperor’s Coronation day— Mr: Harris is also of opinion that Count Romanzoff’s influence is upon the decline; and that the cordiality between this Country and France is not so great as it was some months ago— The Ladies, Mr: Smith and myself dined with General and Madame de Betancourt— He is a Spanish Officer, now in the Russian Service; and she is an English woman. They have two daughters grown up—Caroline and Adeline both very accomplished— And a boy and girl, small children. The Colombi’s—Mr: Navarro—Mr: Harris and the Lady of General Sabloukoff formed the company. General Betancourt’s house is furnished with great elegance— He shewed me several Clocks of the Parisian bronze-work, now so much in fashion; and a watch in the form of a round snuff-box, with the ordinary division of time on one side, and on the other a division of the day into ten hours, and in subordinate decimal divisions to the 100,000th: part or about 5/6 of a second. An ingenious but useless contrivance— After dinner I rode with Mrs: Adams to the Petersburg island and the Kammenoi-Ostrof, and saw the Country with its first appearance of vegetation. After returning home, I walked upon the quay— Visit from Mr: Harris again in the Evening.— Wrote to the Secy: of State.

25. Mr: Harris sent me this morning, the dispatches from Mr: Daschkoff to Count Romanzoff, containing the account of the outrage upon his house on the 26th: of March, and his correspondence afterwards with the Secretary of State, and with Mr: Dallas the District Attorney, respecting it. Mr: Harris afterwards called himself, and gave me a report of the American Commerce with Russia, during the year 1809. I received also visits from Mr: Montreal, and Mr: Dorsey— Mr: Montréal offered me any money for which I might have occasion, to be drawn for at my own convenience— Mr: Harris made me the same obliging offer immediately after my first arrival here— Under the Circumstances in which I find myself here it is difficult to resist the opportunities thus presented for anticipating upon my regular income— But I am determined to do it— The whole experience of my life, has been one continual
proof of the difficulty with which a man can adhere to the principle of living within his income— The first, and most important principle of private economy— From the month of July 1790. when I commenced my Career as a man untill the close of 1793. I was enabled to accomplish this purpose only by the assistance of small supplies from my father— I had then acquired the means of maintaining myself— In 1794. I was sent to Europe, and untill my Marriage in 1797. kept more easily within my bounds than at any preceding or subsequent period— Since I have had a family, I have kept steady to my principle, but at the prices of uncommon sacrifices of consideration and a reputation which in the Spirit of this age, economy cannot escape— In this Country beyond all others, and in my situation more than in any other the temptations to excess in expence amount almost to compulsion— I have withstood them hitherto, and hope for firmness of character to withstand them in future— I declined with thanks Mr: Montréal’s kind offer; as I had that of Mr: Harris— Mr: Dorsey came to say he should go the day after to-morrow for America, and would call to-morrow Evening for our letters— In the Evening I paid a visit to Mr: Six, whom I found unwell, and in bed— While I was there Count Bussche came in; and also complained of being unwell. I took afterwards a short walk, and came home about eleven at Night.

26. Mr: Martin came this morning and requested a Passport from me, for a Mr: Sherburne, who is at Archangel; an American, who is Master of a Russian vessel, and is going, Mr: Martin knows not where. I wish to give all the assistance in my power, to any of my Countrymen, to whom I can render service here— But Mr: Martin has no description of Mr: Sherburne’s person; nor his signature; and though he produced Mr: Harris’s authentication that Sherburne is a native American Citizen, upon Mr: Martin’s other; yet Mr: Harris did not chuse to certify officially the fact— I thought I had no authority to give the Passport. I walked, morning and Evening, and observed the setting-Sun, on this last day of the Solstice. Met Mr: Harris in my Evening walk.

27. Visit from Mr: Adgate, who is going for Philadelphia in the Ship Helvetius belonging to Mr: Girard— I gave him the packet of letters which we had prepared for him, and I ought to have written others— I began indeed a letter for my brother; but some accident having engaged me to a verification of the Russian weights, measures and coins, and this having led to a comparison of them with the weights, measures and coins of France and England, I gave too much of the time which should have been employed in letter writing to this object, and therefore did not finish my letter— Mr: Dorsey and Mr: Plummer visited us in the Evening, but I was out, walking.

28. Day wasted in ascertaining precisely the French Millimeter, Centimeter, Decimeter & Meter— Went in the Evening with the Ladies, and Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray, to the Theatre where we saw a Russian Opera, called the Invisible Prince. I afterwards walked an hour upon the Quay of the Neva— Mr: Adgate called this Evening to take leave; while I was gone out. I had also a visit this morning from Mr: Montréal, who brought me some further accounts of the Russian trade— Mr: Laurance came for a Passport, and to say that he expected to go to-morrow for New-York.

29. Mr: Coffin, an American Gentleman, who arrived here the day before yesterday from Elseneur and Tonningen, paid me this morning a visit, and brought two letters for Mr: J. S. Smith— Mr: Laurance also came for his Passport and informed me that he should go to Cronstadt this Evening— I wrote a letter to my brother. The Sun has now become so powerful at the middle of the day, that I begin to omit the walk before dinner, and only take one of about five miles in the Evening— I walked over the Summer Garden Bridge; and in the return, met General Pardo, and Count Lüxbourg. The General told me that General Betancourt had solved the famous problem of sluices— In a Memoir which has been published by the national Institute at Paris, with great commendation— General Pardo is going to Moscow, and about 500 wersts further to the famous Fair of Makarieff.

30. Pass’d the day at home, without the interruption of any visitors. In the Evening I walked in the Summer Gardens, and over the long Bridge— The width of the river there is by my customary admeasurement 805 of my paces or 2213 feet—at the lower Bridge it is only 364 paces or 1000 feet.— I wrote something this day, but still gave an undue proportion of the time to my enquiries concerning weights measures and coins— My precise object is to ascertain those of Russia, with their relative proportions to those used in America— But I find it extremely difficult, and indeed as yet have not succeeded in fixing
accurately my ideas on the subject— I procured sometime since a Russian Nest of Brass weights from one pound to a quarter of a Zolotnik, and a pair of Scales— I have compared them with an Apothecary’s scale and weights, which we brought with the medecine chest from America. By this comparison I found that the Russian pound was equal to 6312 3/4 grains— But all the smaller Russian weights were incorrect— Some weighing more, and some less than the proportion. The Scales too are so coarsely made that they scarcely indicate any variation of less than a quarter Zolotnik; which is the smallest of the weights they use among the Silversmiths— My apothecary’s balance was much more accurate, and much more sensible to small weights— There are however differences of full half a grain in several of them.— Maudru in his Russian Grammar says that the Russian pound is equal to 409 grammes of the new French standard, and Webster in his Dictionary gives 15.444. grains troy weight for the gramme— Supposing both these correct, the Russian pound will be equal to 6316.596. grains Troy; about three and three quarters of a grain more than I found it by the comparison of the weights and scales. But I had no English weight of more than two drams or 120 grains, and all my apothecary’s weights together amount only to 301 3/4 grains. I was therefore obliged by means of these to make other heavier weights to compare with the larger portions of the Russian pound, and having no smaller weight than 1/4 of a grain I could come within that only by conjecture— These circumstances together with the slight difference in my smallest weights accounting for the difference of 3 3/4 grains between my experiment, and the numbers given by Maudru and Webster. I have considered them as correct, and accordingly take the Russian pound to be = to 6316.596. grains English Troy weight— Maudru is however not exact in his comparisons of the Russian weights and measures with those of France, and Webster, differs from others, and even from himself—for in one page he makes the old Paris Pound as 27 to 25 English Avoirdupois, and in the next he gives a table in which 109. pounds avoirdupois is exhibited is equal to 100 Paris pounds— Storch and George whom I have also consulted, are not more accurate— So that I may still find occasion to correct my present estimate— In round numbers the usual maxim is that 36. Avoirdupois pounds are equal to a Russian pood of 40 pounds— And Mr: Montreal has given me a Memoir of the trade of St: Petersburg, in which he makes the 100 lb. avoirdupois equal to 111 4/16 Russian pounds, in which case, if, as Webster says the English Avoirdupois pound is equal to 7000 grains Troy, the Russian pound would then be only 6292.098 grains Troy. I find also upon examination as much uncertainty, and discrepancy, in the account of measures, as in that of weights.— I collect however some information, and put my researches in a train which may terminate in some useful knowledge.

Day. Since our removal to our present apartments, my situation is much more comfortable than it was at the Ville de Bordeaux. I have now a chamber to my self, for writing and study; which I had not there— But we are scarcely settled in our lodgings, and I am still much interrupted by visitors— I rise between 6 and 10. without any regularity— Breakfast at 10. Pass the morning and untill 5 in the afternoon in my writing chamber; reading, writing or receiving visits— From 5 to 7. at dinner. Then an hour or two in my chamber—an hour and a half walking— From 10 to Midnight playing chess or Cards, or with the Ladies and their visitors— Twelve is the hour for bed.— The variations from this course are occasional; when I dine abroad; have company to dine at home— Walk an hour between 3 and 5. before dinner; or pay visits, morning or Evening. I have finished the perusal of the Old Testament; but my Russian studies have given way for weights, measures and Coins.
